importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was published on October 21, 2025, and is part of a broader discussion on internet platform degradation, reflecting current societal concerns about digital monopolies and platform governance.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The article references key developments in the discourse on enshittification, particularly the 2023 American Dialect Society word of the year and Merriam-Webster's inclusion of the term, placing it within a recent cultural and linguistic shift in public discourse.

keyTakeAways: The term 'enshittification' describes how internet platforms degrade over time, shifting from user-friendly early stages to exploitative, profit-driven models.

Doctorow outlines three stages of enshittification: (1) user acquisition through attractive pricing and network effects, (2) business customer favoritism at user expense, and (3) profit maximization at the expense of both users and merchants.

Platforms like Facebook, Google, Amazon, and Uber are cited as examples where data exploitation, predatory pricing, and algorithmic manipulation have led to deteriorating experiences for users and small businesses.
Amazon is accused of cloning products, charging junk fees (up to 51 cents per dollar earned), and distorting search results, with the first result being 29% more expensive than the best match.
Doctorow argues that the lack of competition and weak consumer protection regulations allow platforms to treat users as expendable, protected by network effects and high switching costs.

Proposed solutions include antitrust enforcement, abandoning the consumer welfare standard, implementing a 'right-to-exit' policy (e.g., allowing users to take data with them), and promoting interoperability (e.g., allowing cross-platform app and device compatibility).

namedEntities.name: Cory Doctorow
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Internet activist, journalist, and author who coined the term 'enshittification' and wrote the book of the same name.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Doctorow is the central figure whose theory of enshittification provides the foundation of the article, explaining how internet platforms degrade over time due to profit-driven behavior.

namedEntities.name: enshittification
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A term coined by Cory Doctorow describing the process by which internet platforms become worse over time, shifting from user-friendly beginnings to exploitative, profit-maximizing models.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This concept is the central thesis of the article, used to explain the decline of platforms like Facebook, Amazon, and Uber.

namedEntities.name: Facebook (Meta)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A social media platform that Doctorow claims has undergone enshittification, particularly through changes to user feeds and ad targeting.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Facebook is a primary example used in the article to illustrate how platforms evolve from user-focused to profit-driven models, especially in stages 2 and 3.

namedEntities.name: Google
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A search engine and internet platform that Doctorow includes in his analysis of enshittification.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Google is cited as a platform that initially served users well but has since shifted focus to business customers and algorithmic ad targeting, contributing to platform degradation.

namedEntities.name: Amazon
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An e-commerce platform accused by Doctorow of enshittification through predatory pricing, product cloning, and junk fees.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Amazon is a central case study, with claims that it charges sellers up to 51 cents per dollar earned in fees and distorts search results to favor its own products.

namedEntities.name: Uber
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A transportation platform included in Doctorow's list of platforms undergoing enshittification.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Uber is used as an example of how platforms transition from user-friendly beginnings to exploitative business models, though less detailed than Amazon or Facebook.

namedEntities.name: American Dialect Society
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An organization that named 'enshittification' its word of the year in 2023.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The recognition of the term by this society highlights its cultural and linguistic significance, indicating widespread public awareness and acceptance of the concept.

namedEntities.name: Merriam-Webster
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A dictionary publisher that added 'enshittification' to its dictionary despite its swear-word origin.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This reflects the growing legitimacy and acceptance of the term in mainstream discourse and public understanding.

namedEntities.name: Institute for Local Self-Reliance
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A non-profit organization cited by Doctorow as a source for the claim that Amazon sellers lose 45–51 cents per dollar earned.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provides a data-backed foundation for the economic claims made about Amazon’s impact on merchants.

namedEntities.name: consumer welfare standard
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A legal doctrine used in antitrust cases that evaluates monopolistic behavior based on consumer harm through price increases.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Doctorow argues this doctrine is outdated and insufficient, advocating for a shift to more consumer-protective regulations.

namedEntities.name: interoperability
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A technical concept allowing products or services to work together across platforms, such as printers using third-party ink.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Doctorow promotes interoperability as a way to reduce market power and enable competition, countering artificial barriers set by tech companies.

namedEntities.name: right-to-exit
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A policy proposal suggesting users can take their data or content (e.g., e-books) with them when leaving a platform.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is presented as a key regulatory solution to improve user trust and incentivize platforms to treat users fairly.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Cory Doctorow’s new book and theory of 'enshittification' explains how internet platforms like Facebook, Google, Amazon, and Uber degrade over time — starting with user-friendly, growth-oriented phases and progressing to exploitative, profit-driven models where users and businesses are treated poorly. Doctorow outlines three stages: (1) user acquisition through network effects and attractive deals; (2) favoring business customers at the expense of users; and (3) squeezing profits through predatory pricing, algorithmic manipulation, and high fees. Amazon is accused of charging sellers up to 51 cents per dollar earned, distorting search results, and cloning products, while Facebook is criticized for algorithmic ad targeting and forcing publishers to publish longer content. The root causes are attributed to a lack of competition and weak regulation, particularly the consumer welfare standard. Doctorow proposes solutions including stronger antitrust enforcement, the 'right-to-exit' policy, and increased interoperability between platforms to restore fairness and competition in digital services.
title: A theory why the internet is going down the toilet
